{{good article}} {{Infobox summit | summit_name = 2010 G-20 Toronto summit | other_titles = | image = 2010 G-20 Toronto summit logo.svg | caption = | country = Canada | venues = [[Metro Toronto Convention Centre]] | cities = [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]] | date = June 26â27, 2010 | precedes = [[2010 G-20 Seoul summit]] | follows = [[2009 G-20 Pittsburgh summit]] | website = [http://canadainternational.gc.ca/g20/summit-sommet/2010/toronto-toronto.aspx?lang=eng&menu_id=3&menu=L Official website] }} The '''2010 G-20 Toronto summit''' was the [[List of G-20 summits|fourth meeting]] of the [[G-20 major economies|G-20]] [[Head of government|heads of government]], in discussion of the [[global financial system]] and the [[world economy]], which took place at the [[Metro Toronto Convention Centre]] in [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada, during June 26â27, 2010. The summit's priorities included evaluating the progress of financial reform, developing sustainable stimulus measures,<ref>http://www.economicsummits.info/2010/03/harpers-comments-to-the-sherpas-document/</ref> debating [[bank tax|global bank tax]],<ref>{{cite news|author=Canada |url=http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/g8-g20/background-summit-issues/article1547024/ |title=Background: Summit Issues |publisher=Globe and Mail |date=April 28, 2010 |accessdate=2010-06-20 |location=Toronto}}</ref> and promoting [[open market]]s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pm.gc.ca/eng/media.asp?id=3209 |title=Prime Minister of Canada: Statement by the Prime Minister of Canada |publisher=Pm.gc.ca |date= |accessdate=2010-05-20}}</ref> Alongside the twenty-one representatives of the G-20 major economies, leaders of six invited nations, and eight additional [[intergovernmental organization]]s also took part in the summit.
Prior to the summit, [[Prime Minister of Canada|Canadian prime minister]] [[Stephen Harper]] announced that the theme of the Toronto summit would be "recovery and new beginnings," referring to an anticipated [[economic stimulus]] from the impact of the [[Late-2000s recession|ongoing world recession]].<ref>http://www.economicsummits.info/2010/03/harpers-comments-to-the-sherpas-document/</ref> The summit was initially proposed to be held in the town of [[Huntsville, Ontario]], where the immediately preceding [[36th G8 summit]] was set to be held. The town was later deemed insufficient to provide hospitality for the large number of G-20 delegates and journalists, thus the summit was later finalized to take place in Toronto.<ref name=washingtonexaminer1>{{cite web|author=6:26 EDT |url=http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/world/canada-says-spending-nearly-1-billion-on-security-for-g-8-and-g-20-summits-is-worth-it-95107194.html |title=Canada says spending nearly {{Nowrap|$1 billion}} on security for G8 and G-20 summits is worth it |publisher=Washington Examiner |date=2010-05-28 |accessdate=2010-06-04}}</ref>
An [[Integrated Security Unit]], consisting of police officers from different regional departments, was formed to provide security during the summit in [[Downtown Toronto]],<ref>{{cite web|author=Toronto Police Service |url=http://www.torontopolice.on.ca/g20/ |title=Toronto Police Service :: To Serve and Protect |publisher=Torontopolice.on.ca |date= |accessdate=2010-05-20}}</ref> where the venue was located. The event was part of the largest and most expensive security operation in [[History of Canada|Canadian history]]. The total cost for preparations,<ref>{{cite web|author=Alcoba, Natalie|url=http://network.nationalpost.com/NP/blogs/toronto/archive/2010/02/22/g8-g20-gearing-up-for-the-biggest-security-event-in-canadian-history.aspx#ixzz0gXPVjsqt |title=G8/G20: Gearing up for the biggest security event in Canadian history|publisher=Posted Toronto |date= |accessdate=2010-06-20}}</ref> including security, infrastructure, and hospitality, was determined to be approximately [[Canadian dollar|C$]]858 million.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/toronto/story/2010/11/05/g20-costs-tabled.html |title=CBC News â Toronto â G8/G20 costs top $857M |publisher=Cbc.ca |date=2010-11-05 |accessdate=2010-11-05}}</ref>
==Agenda== Many leaders of the [[G-20 major economies|G-20]] were divided among different issues that they wanted to discuss at the summit.<ref>Wolverson, Roya. [http://www.cfr.org/publication/22542/g20s_twenty_agendas.html?breadcrumb=%2Fpublication%2Fby_type%2Fbackgrounder "The G20's Twenty Agendas,"] ''Council on Foreign Relations'' (US). June 24, 2010, retrieved 2011-04-06</ref> The prime focus of the summit discussions was the recovery from the ongoing [[Late-2000s recession|global recession]] and the [[2010 European sovereign debt crisis|European debt crisis]]. Summit leaders were divided over which strategies would be best for tackling these problems. The [[European Union]] emphasized the need to cut their deficits by focusing on [[austerity]] measures. In contrast, the [[United States]] emphasized the importance of maintaining [[economic stimulus]] spending in order to encourage growth.<ref>[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/2010/06/2010627114252622620.html "Recession recovery tops G20 agenda,"] ''Al Jazeera'' (Qatar). June 28, 2010, retrieved 2011-04-06</ref> In summit discussions, the countries of the European Union explained projected reductions in spending and balanced budgets. A different approach was projected by the [[People's Republic of China|China]], India, and the United States, arguing in favor of increased stimulus funding to mitigate the effects of recession. Among the specifics proposed by the European Union were a global [[bank tax]] and a [[Robin Hood tax]], but these plans were opposed by the United States and [[Canada]].<ref>Davies, Rhodri. [http://english.aljazeera.net/focus/2010/06/201062571713780493.html "G20:Battles within and outside,"] ''Al Jazeera'' (Qatar). June 28, 2010, retrieved 2011-04-06.</ref> Other topics of concern were [[international development]] and continuing [[international aid]] to [[Africa]] and other developing nations.<ref>[http://english.aljazeera.net/programmes/insidestory/2010/06/2010624125511683950.html "Forgotten goals,"] ''Al Jazeera'' (Qatar). June 28, 2010, retrieved 2011-04-06.</ref> Criticism of [[Israel]]'s [[Blockade of the Gaza Strip|Gaza strip blockade]] and criticism of the nuclear programs of [[North Korea]] was expressed. Issues of corruption and security in [[Afghanistan]] was raised by the United States.
== Preparations == {{Main|2010 G-20 Toronto summit preparations}} === Security === [[File:Fences Are Up Toronto 2010.jpg|thumb|right|Security fencing erected along the middle of Wellington Street]] Security officials began preparing for summit security in Toronto around mid-February 2010.<ref>[http://www.g8-g20isu.ca/g20/about-apropos-eng.htm Integrated Security Unit (ISU)]: [http://www.g8-g20isu.ca/g20/news-nouvelles/10-02-19-eng.htm "Metro Toronto Convention Centre will be the official venue of the G20 Summit in Toronto in June,"] February 19, 2010.</ref> General policing and patrolling was provided by the [[Toronto Police Service]], the [[Ontario Provincial Police]], the [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police]], and the [[Canadian Forces]], while the [[Peel Regional Police]] aided in policing at [[Toronto Pearson International Airport]] in [[Mississauga]] during the arrivals of delegates. The five departments formed an [[Integrated Security Unit]] (ISU), similar to the ISU created during the [[2010 Winter Olympics]] in [[Vancouver]]. Additional officers were deployed from [[York Regional Police]], [[Halton Regional Police Service]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/2010/06/22/peter-kuitenbrouwer-downtown-doesnt-feel-like-home-during-g20/ |title=Peter Kuitenbrouwer: Downtown doesnât feel like home during G20 | Posted Toronto | National Post |publisher=News.nationalpost.com |date=2010-06-21 |accessdate=2010-06-29}}</ref> [[Barrie Police Service]], [[Waterloo Regional Police Service]], [[Niagara Regional Police Service]], [[Hamilton Police Service]], [[Ottawa Police Service]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.insidetoronto.com/news/article/839309--protesters-gather-at-allan-gardens-to-oppose-g20-summit |title=Protesters gather at Allan Gardens to oppose G20 Summit |publisher=InsideToronto Article |date=2010-06-25 |accessdate=2010-06-29}}</ref> and [[Service de police de la Ville de MontrÃ©al]]. [[Calgary Police Service]] supplied 150 volunteer police officers a week before the summit.<ref>{{cite web|author=Calgary Herald June 14, 2010 |url=http://www.calgaryherald.com/news/Calgary+police+head+Toronto+massive+security+effort/3150428/story.html |title=Calgary police head to Toronto for massive G20 security effort |publisher=Calgaryherald.com |date=2010-06-14 |accessdate=2010-06-22}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>

== Protests == {{Main|2010 G-20 Toronto summit protests}} [[File:G-20 Toronto June 2010 (20).jpg|thumb|right|Demonstrators holding signs with slogans against the G-20]] The Toronto summit was the target of widespread protesting which occurred in [[Downtown Toronto]] during the week of the summit. Early opposition to the G-20 included an incident in [[Ottawa]] where a bank was firebombed by [[anarchism|anarchists]], who claimed they would be present during the G-20 summit in Toronto.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/ottawa/story/2010/05/18/ott-glebe-bank-fire.html |title=RBC firebombed as protest, group claims |publisher=CBC (Canada) |date= May 8, 20108|accessdate=2010-09-28 }}</ref> The perceived security threat caused the [[Integrated Security Unit]] to increase security measures.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thestar.com/news/gta/article/812976--ottawa-firebombing-proves-security-need-clement-says |title=Ottawa firebombing proves security need, Clement says |publisher=''Toronto Star'' (Canada) |date= May 21, 2010 |accessdate=2010-09-28 | first=Gail | last=Swainson}}</ref>

news|url=http://ca.reuters.com/article/topNews/idCATRE65E4RB20100617?pageNumber=1&virtualBrandChannel=0 |title=Toronto G20 protest hints at more to come|publisher=Reuters (Canada) |date=2009-02-09 2010-06-22|accessdate=2010-06-24 | first1=Jennifer | last1=Yang | first2=Liam | last2=Casey}}</ref> [[capitalism]] and [[globalization]],<ref>{{cite As the first day of the summit approached, protesters grew in numbers. Several streets were closed down for demonstrations on the debut of the summit. Peaceful protests were followed by [[black bloc]] tactics as individuals dressed in black dispersed from the crowd and began damaging the windows of particular businesses across Downtown Toronto, mostly [[List of fast food restaurants|fast food chains]], retail stores and banks, as well as local businesses.<ref>{{cite news|author=The Canadian Press |url=http://www.thestar.com/news/gta/torontog20summit/article/829168--violent-black-bloc-tactics-on-display-at-g20-protest?bn=1 |title=Violent Black Bloc tactics on display at G20 protest |publisher=thestar.com |date= 2010-06-26|accessdate=2010-06-27 | location=Toronto}}</ref> [[Police car|Police cruisers]] were set on fire and vehicles of media corporations were damaged.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://toronto.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20100626/summit-protests-100626/20100626/?hub=TorontoNewHome |title=CTV Toronto â Police attempt to clear crowds amid G20 unrest â CTV News |publisher=Toronto.ctv.ca |date=2010-04-29 |accessdate=2010-06-27}}</ref> Nearby hospitals, shopping centres, and hotels were put in a [[lockdown]] mode while public transit services were diverted from Downtown to other locations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://toronto.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20100626/toronto-chaos-100626/20100626/?hub=TorontoNewHome |title=CTV Toronto â TTC lines, Eaton Centre locked down as protests heat up â CTV News |publisher=Toronto.ctv.ca |date= |accessdate=2010-06-27}}</ref>

== Outcome == [[File:Leaders at the 2010 G-20 Toronto summit.jpg|thumb|right|Leaders confer at the [[Metro Toronto Convention Centre]] on June 27]] Prior to the Toronto summit, it was speculated that it would not see the same outcome as previous summits. This was partially due to most countries' entering recovery mode from the [[Late-2000s recession|global economic recession]] after the past [[List of G-20 summits|G-20 summits]]; thus, the likelihood of new issues being raised was minimal.<ref>[http://opinion.globaltimes.cn/commentary/2010-06/544784_2.html "No high hopes for G20 summit outcome."] ''Global Times'' (PRC). June 23, 2010, retrieved 2011-04-08.</ref>
During the working dinner for G-20 leaders on the evening of June 26, South African president [[Jacob Zuma]] promoted more partnership between the international community and Africa for the development in the continent. "As Africa we bring to the G20 Summit the key message that we must, together as the developing and developed worlds, promote stronger and more effective and equal international partnerships for growth and development," he remarked.<ref>[http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=6&art_id=nw20100627065853768C239086 "Zuma urges more partnerships at G20 dinner,"] ''Independent'' (South Africa). June 27, 2010, retrieved 2011-04-08.</ref>
At the summit, US president [[Barack Obama]] warned that global recovery was still "fragile." In hopes of boosting American exports, he announced the proposal of a [[free trade agreement]] between the [[United States]] and [[South Korea]].<ref>Schneider, Howard. [http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/06/26/AR2010062604314.html?sid=ST2010062604320 "President Obama urges G-20 nations to spend; they pledge to halve deficits,"] ''Washington Post'' (US). June 28, 2010, retrieved 2011-04-08.</ref> A key agreement the leaders of [[Developed country|developed nations]] made was to cut annual budget deficits in half by 2013.<ref name="autogenerated3">{{cite web|url=http://www.cp24.com/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20100628/100628_harper_g20/20100628/?hub=CP24Home |title=Harper applauds summit outcome but says G20 still has a lot more to do â CTV News, Shows and Sports â Canadian Television |publisher=CP24 |date= |accessdate=2010-09-07}}</ref> The leaders also agreed on reducing [[debt-to-GDP ratio]] in each economy by 2016.<ref name="autogenerated3"/> The debate on imposing a [[bank tax|tax on financial institutions]] was settled as the group decided that [[financial institution]]s would be required to make fair contributions to recover costs from the financial sector reform,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bundesfinanzministerium.de/EN/Topics/International-affairs/Articles/20100816-Outcome-of-the-Toronto-G20-summit.html |title=Bundesministerium der Finanzen: Outcome of the Toronto G20 summit |publisher=Bundesfinanzministerium.de |date=2010-06-29 |accessdate=2010-09-07}}</ref> but the way the contributions would be collected would be up to each government.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thestar.com/news/gta/torontog20summit/article/829266--g20-adopts-canadian-compromise-on-deficits-bank-tax |title=G20 adopts Canadian compromise on deficits, bank tax |publisher=thestar.com |date=2010-06-27 |accessdate=2010-09-07 | location=Toronto | first1=Les | last1=Whittingon | first2=Bruce | last2=Campion-Smith | first3=Richard J. | last3=Brennan}}</ref> It was also decided that institutions would be required to keep a higher amount of [[financial capital]] in case of future [[Shock (economics)|financial shocks]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.financialtaskforce.org/2010/04/23/g20-finance-ministers-communique-is-released/ |title=G20 Finance Ministers CommuniquÃ© is Released Â« Task Force on Financial Integrity and Economic Development |publisher=Financialtaskforce.org |date=2010-04-23 |accessdate=2010-09-07}}</ref> [[Climate change]] and [[food security]] were also discussed; the leaders reiterated their commitment to a "[[environmentally friendly|greener]] growth".<ref>{{cite web|last=Spence |first=Chris |url=http://climate-l.org/news/g-20-toronto-summit-addresses-energy-subsidies-climate-change-and-food-security/ |title=G-20 Toronto Summit Addresses Energy Subsidies, Climate Change and Food Security |publisher=Climate-L.org |date=2010-06-27 |accessdate=2010-09-07}}</ref>
''The G-20 Toronto Summit Declaration'', which was released shortly after the summit concluded, stated that "serious challenges remain."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.globaltvbc.com/Full+text+Toronto+summit+declaration/3208712/story.html |title=Full text: The G20 Toronto summit declaration |publisher=Globaltvbc.com |date=2010-06-27 |accessdate=2010-09-02}}</ref> According to the document, the challenges include high unemployment rates in various economies and the concurrent existence of the impact of the [[Late-2000s financial crisis|financial crisis]]. The [[International Monetary Fund]], in its post-summit document, indicated that a speedy cut in deficits may substantially slow growth. In a publication titled ''Top Ten Commandments for Fiscal Adjustment in Advanced Economies'', the organization insisted that balanced public spending could stabilize [[bond market]]s, reduce interest rates from less government spending, and encourage private investment. It also recommended that emerging economies such as [[China]], which has largely benefited from trade surpluses, rely less on developed nations and increase their own spending in order to promote domestic demand.<ref>{{cite news|author=Post Store |url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/06/27/AR2010062702887.html |title=G-20 Toronto Summit Declaration |publisher=Washingtonpost.com |date=2010-06-27 |accessdate=2010-09-02}}</ref>
==Criticism== ===Financial costs=== The financial costs of hosting the [[36th G8 summit|G8]] and G-20 summits was the topic of several political debates and the target of criticism by local groups.<ref>Rider, David. [http://www.thestar.com/news/gta/torontog20summit/article/769614--toronto-warns-ottawa-on-g20-costs "Toronto warns Ottawa on G20 costs,"] ''Toronto Star'' (Canada). February 22, 2010, retrieved 2011-04-10</ref> The reasons for the large price for both summits were questioned by a few politicians and local groups. Members of Parliament [[Olivia Chow]] and [[Mark Holland]] labelled the initially claimed budget of $1.1-billion for hosting the summits as "obscene" and "insane" while others argued that the money could have been used for long-pending municipal projects in Canada,<ref name="security">[http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/Canada/20100528/g8-g20-costs-page-100528/?s_name=&no_ads= "Security chief defends high cost of G8-G20 summits,"] CTV (Canada). May 28, 2010, retrieved 2011-04-10; Sufrin, Jon. [http://www.torontolife.com/daily/informer/summit-survivor/2010/05/26/833-million-security-bill-for-g20-and-g8-called-insane/ "$833-million security bill for G20 and G8 called 'insane',"] ''Toronto Life'' (Canada). May 26, 2010,retrieved 2011-04-10</ref> such as Toronto's [[Transit City]].<ref>Pate, Stephen. [http://www.oyetimes.com/views/columns/3186-1-billion-price-tag-for-g20-security-and-climbing "$1 billion price tag for G20 security and climbing,"] ''Oye! Times'' (Canada). June 27, 2010,retrieved 2011-04-10</ref> The security cost for the two summits was believed to be more expensive than the combined security costs of the [[2010 Winter Olympics]] and [[2010 Winter Paralympics|Paralympics]] in [[Vancouver]] and [[Whistler, British Columbia]], which were {{Nowrap|$878 million}}.<ref>Sufrin, Jon. [http://www.torontolife.com/daily/informer/summit-survivor/2010/05/26/833-million-security-bill-for-g20-and-g8-called-insane/ "$833-million security bill for G20 and G8 called 'insane',"] ''Toronto Life'' (Canada). May 26, 2010, retrieved 2011-00004-10</ref> However, according to final calculations from the [[House of Commons of Canada]] as of October 2010, the exact cost for holding both summits was $857,901,850.31,<ref>[http://www.cbc.ca/canada/toronto/story/2010/11/05/g20-costs-tabled.html "G8/G20 costs top $857M,"] CBC/Radio-Canada (Canada). November 5, 2010, retrieved 2011-04-10.</ref> making it less expensive than the security costs for the 2010 Winter Olympics.
It was initially claimed that the summits stand as the most expensive ever held, with security costs for the [[2009 G-20 London Summit|London]] and [[2009 G-20 Pittsburgh summit|Pittsburgh]] G-20 summits in 2009 reported as having been only {{Nowrap|$30 million}} and {{Nowrap|$18 million}}, respectively.<ref name="security"/> However, the Canadian [[Parliamentary Budget Officer]], [[Kevin Page]], stated in his official report on the costs of the Huntsville and Toronto gatherings that other countries had not been as open about the full price for the similar meetings held there and that the {{Nowrap|$18 million}} figure for the Pittsburgh summit was merely for overtime pay for local police and the cost of law enforcement brought in from other regions.<ref>Tibbetts, Jane. "Tories 'transparent' on security costs: watchdog," ''Ottawa Citizen'' (Canada). June 24, 2010.</ref> [[Ward Elcock]], former [[Canadian Security Intelligence Service]] director and the chief of the [[Integrated Security Unit]]s for the Winter Olympics and the G8/G-20 summits, claimed that the security costs were in fact "comparable" with those of previous summits.<ref name="security"/> Finance minister [[Jim Flaherty]] defended the security cost, claiming "it's necessary to spend substantially to have security. It's Canada's turn, and it's necessary that we either don't take our turn or pay the appropriate price to have the security that is necessary so that everyone is safe here in Toronto."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://winnipeg.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20100607/flaherty_cost_100607/20100607/?hub=WinnipegHome |title=Financial reform taking too long: Flaherty |publisher=CTV (Canada) |date=June 7, 2010 |accessdate=2010-09-28}}</ref>
The creation of the $23-million international media centre, which included the {{Nowrap|$1.9 million}} ''Experience Canada'' pavilion and $57,000 artificial lake, at the [[Exhibition Place]] was widely opposed and criticized by politicians as "a waste of taxpayers' money."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://looncanada.wordpress.com/2010/06/08/g20-summit-fake-lake-has-canadian-taxpayers-in-stitches/ |title=G20 summit's {{Nowrap|$2 million}} "fake lake" has Canadian taxpayers in stitches |publisher=''Loon'' (Canada) |date=June 28, 2010 |accessdate= 2010-09-28}}</ref> Criticism mostly targeted Stephen Harper and Canada's [[Conservative Party of Canada|Conservative government]]. Some protesting groups gave names to the artificial lake, such as "Harper's Folly".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/TopStories/20100607/g20-security-cost-100607/ |title=Tories say artificial lake will help 'showcase Canada'|publisher=CTV (Canada) |date= June 7, 2010|accessdate=2010-09-28 }}</ref> In a debate in the House of Commons, Mark Holland said, "Instead of hosting world leaders, maybe the government should consider party planning for [[Lady Gaga]]."<ref>Weese, Bryn. {{cite web|url=http://www.torontosun.com/news/canada/2010/06/07/14291091.html |title='Fake lake' flak dogs PM |publisher=''Toronto Sun'' (Canada) |date= June 7, 2010|accessdate=2010-09-28 }}</ref> According to some critics, the spending misled the objective of the summits into showing off Canada's attributes instead of promoting the summits' agendas.<ref name="taber">Taber, Jane. {{cite news|url=http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/ottawa-notebook/tories-pilloried-for-fake-lake-at-g8g20-media-centre/article1595348/ |title=Tories pilloried for fake lake at G8/G20 media centre |publisher=''Globe and Mail'' (Canada) |date= June 7, 201|accessdate=2010-09-28 |location=Toronto |first=Jane |last=Taber}}</ref> [[New Democratic Party]] leader [[Jack Layton]] condemned the Harper government, saying, "we've got a government here that has to create an artificial lake when Canada has more lakes than just about any other country in the world. It is the taxpayers who are going to end up at the bottom of the fake lake." Transport minister [[John Baird (Canadian politician)|John Baird]] defended the artificial lake, saying that the summits gave a "chance to showcase the very best that [Canada] has to offer." Foreign affairs minister [[Lawrence Cannon]] said it was "normal practice" for a country to showcase its attributes while hosting world events.<ref name="taber" /> Harper also defended by saying, "This is a classic attempt for us to be able to market the country."<ref>Arkin, David. {{cite web|url=http://www.nationalpost.com/news/Tories+splash+back+critics+over+cost+lake/3128209/story.html |title=Tories splash back on cost of G20 'lake' |publisher=''National Post'' (Canada) |date= June 8, 2010 |accessdate=2010-09-28 }}</ref> Upon its opening, the artificial lake received mixed reviews from Canadian reporters.<ref>Rider, David. {{cite news|url=http://www.thestar.com/news/gta/torontog20summit/article/827453--g20-fake-lake-makes-its-debut |title=G20 'Fake Lake' makes its debut |publisher=''Toronto Star'' (Canada) |date=June 23, 2010 |accessdate= 2010-09-28 | first=David | last=Rider}}</ref>
===Economic impact=== The summit's economic impact was a major concern of a few local politicians and citizens. The [[municipal government of Toronto]], as well as some public representatives, previously argued that the G-20 summit should be held at an isolated venue, such as the [[Exhibition Place]], rather than the [[Metro Toronto Convention Centre]], which is located in the city's [[central business district]].<ref>"G8, G20 security costs will surpass Olympics, officials say," ''Ottawa Citizen'' (Canada). February 23, 2010.</ref> As a result, during the aftermath of [[#Protests|the protests during the summit]], when several business and properties in [[Downtown Toronto]] were damaged, mayor [[David Miller (Canadian politician)|David Miller]] urged the federal government to compensate for all the damages. It was initially outlined by the government that only damages to businesses within the security zone would be compensated. However, all damages occurred outside of the security zone. Some businesses in the downtown core suffered financially as a result.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://toronto.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20100629/toronto-riot-compensation-businesses-100629/20100629/?hub=TorontoNewHome |title=Advocates want compensation for T.O. businesses |publisher=CTV (Toronto) |date= June 26, 2010|accessdate=2010-09-28}}</ref> According to Member of Parliament [[John McCallum]], "Stephen Harper made a huge mistake in holding this summit in downtown Toronto." According to the ''[[Toronto Star]]'', at least 40 stores in the [[Downtown Yonge|Downtown Yonge Business Improvement Area]] suffered damages and one repair firm performed up to {{nowrap|$750,000}} in repairs.<ref>Ridder, David and Susan Delacourt. {{cite news|url=http://www.thestar.com/news/gta/article/829912--pressure-builds-on-ottawa-for-compensation?bn=1 |title=Pressure builds on Ottawa for compensation |publisher=''Toronto Star'' (Canada) |date= June 29, 2010 |accessdate=2010-09-28 | first1=David | last1=Rider | first2=Susan | last2=Delacourt}}</ref>
===International response=== On June 17, the [[United States Department of State]] issued a travel alert for Toronto, warning tourists of the expected traffic disruptions and potentially violent protests during the G-20 summit. The alert, which was expected to expire on the last day of the summit, stated that "Even demonstrations that are meant to be peaceful can become violent and unpredictable."<ref>McLean, Jesse. [http://www.thestar.com/news/gta/torontog20summit/article/824844--u-s-issues-g20-travel-alert-for-toronto?bn=1 "U.S. issues G20 travel alert for Toronto,"] ''Toronto Star'' (Canada). June 18, 2010, retrieved 2011-04-08</ref> Toronto Mayor [[David Miller (Canadian politician)|David Miller]] described the warning as an "over-reaction."<ref>Meaney, Ken. "U.S. travel warning an over-reaction: Toronto mayor," ''Vancouver Sun'' (Canada). June 18, 2010.</ref>
During the midst of Toronto summit, a few overseas reporters commented on Canada and the summits. A reporter of the [[BBC|British Broadcasting Corporation]] (BBC) made positive remarks about Canada's economy, saying "The Canadians, it seems, have answers for even the toughest puzzles and they are keen to share their strategies with the rest of the world. Why in this economy, we all want to be Canadian." A writer in ''[[The New York Times]]'' made positive comments about the summits' preparations and natural beauty of the [[District Municipality of Muskoka|Muskoka]] region. ''[[The Times of India]]'' and ''[[The Hindu]]'' commented on impacts on city life in Toronto due to the G-20 summit and the "unprecedented" security measures taken in Canada. A [[Reuters]] reporter, on the other hand, condemned the international media centre's artificial lake.<ref>[http://www.cp24.com/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20100626/100626_cost_g20/20100626/?hub=CP24Home "World media buzzing about cost of G20 security and fake lake,"] Canadian Press (Canada). June 23, 2010, retrieved 2011-04-08.</ref>
Looking forward, French president [[Nicolas Sarkozy]] announced that the costs for hosting the [[2011 G-20 Cannes summit|proposed G8 and G-20 summits in France in 2011]] would be one-tenth of Canada's.<ref>[http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/g8-g20/news/sarkozy-says-his-g8g20-will-cost-one-tenth-of-canadas/article1619637/ "Sarkozy says his G8/G20 will cost one-tenth of Canadaâs,"] ''Globe and Mail'' (Canada). June 27, 2010, retrieved 2011-04-08.</ref>
